What sadness reigns over the plain,</br>How droop the sweet flow'rets around,</br>How pensive each nymph and each swain,</br>How silent each heart-pleasing sound!
No more the soft lute in the bow'r</br>Beguiles the blithe ev'nings away,</br>But sighs measure out the dull hour,</br>Since Damon has wander'd astray.
O!  he was the village's pride,</br>This chance from his absence is seen;</br>'Twas he that our music supply'd</br>When we merrily danc'd on the green.
At the shearing, the wake, and the fair,</br>How jovial and frolic were we!</br>But now ev'ry feast in the year</br>Is as joyless as joyless may be.
Oh!  why did he wander away?</br>'Tis the war that has call'd him to arms,</br>And, weeping, he cry'd, "Who can stay</br>When his country resounds with alarms?"
Yet sure he at home should have staid,</br>And left to rough soldiers the war;</br>He only for love could be made,</br>Who is lovely beyond all compare.
Wher'er the adventurer goes,</br>On the land or the dangerous main;</br>Kind Heaven!  protect him from woes,</br>And give him to Celia again.
O!  give him to Celia again—</br>To his true-love my shepherd restore;</br>On his bosom I'll cease to complain,</br>From my arms he shall venture no more.
But, alas!  while thus fondly I sing,</br>Perhaps my love bleeding may lie;</br>Break beneath my stopt fingers each string—</br>To the depth of the thickets I'll fly.
There, hid from each eye, I'll bewail</br>My cruel disasters in love,</br>'Till echo shall learn the sad tale,</br>And repeat it through all the still grove.
But why these vain fears in my breast?</br>Let all sad suggestions be drown'd;</br>With success my brave swain shall be blest,</br>And with titles and honours be crown'd.
Then, then he will make me his bride,</br>For I know he does constant remain,</br>And we'll dwell on yon mountain's fair side,</br>Like the King and the Queen of the plain.</br>
